question.text: All the following options regarding blood transfusion is incorrect, except

options.text: The recipient plasma should not contain antigens against antibodies present in donor plasma.
The donor RBCs should not contain antibodies against an antigen in recipient plasma.
The recipient plasma should not contain antibodies against donor RBC antigens.
The recipient RBCs should not have antigens found on donor RBCs.

solution.text: Blood transfusion means receiving blood into one's circulation intravenously. Antigens are present on the surface of erythrocytes (RBC), whereas antibodies are present in blood plasma. For example, a person with blood group B has surface antigen B on RBC's and antibodies to antigen A in its plasma. Hence, when RBCs are donated, the transfer of antibodies does not take place. However, as the RBCs of the donor have a surface antigen, it should be ensured that the recipient's plasma should not contain antibodies against the antigen on red blood capsules of the donor. Otherwise, if transfusion is made between incompatible donor and recipient, the reaction between the antigens on the donor's RBCs and antibody in the recipient plasma will produce clot and blocked capillaries.
